definitions: existing as a natural or basic part of something that cannot be separated
forming an essential or fundamental element that defines the nature of something
examples: There are inherent risks in mountain climbing activities
The inherent beauty of the landscape captivated everyone
These problems are inherent to the system design
He recognized the inherent contradictions in the argument

definitions: received as a legacy or possession from someone who has died
transmitted genetically from parent organisms to their offspring through heredity
examples: She inherited wealth from her grandmother's estate
The inherited property included several valuable paintings
His inherited traits include his father's blue eyes
Some diseases are inherited through genetic mutations

definitions: in the process of receiving property, title, or characteristics from predecessors
examples: The inheriting children divided the estate equally
She is inheriting her mother's artistic talents gradually

definitions: unable to act naturally or express feelings freely due to self-consciousness
prevented or slowed down from happening or developing by external factors
examples: She felt inhibited at the formal dinner party
His inhibited personality made dating difficult for him
The inhibited growth resulted from poor soil conditions
Chemical reactions were inhibited by the cold temperature

definitions: not friendly or welcoming to guests; showing no hospitality to visitors
providing no shelter or sustenance; too harsh or difficult for living
examples: The inhospitable locals refused to help the travelers
Their inhospitable attitude made everyone uncomfortable immediately
The inhospitable desert offered no water or shade
Mars has an inhospitable environment for human life

definitions: lacking human qualities of compassion, kindness, or mercy; extremely cruel
not human in nature or character; beyond normal human ability or endurance
examples: The inhuman treatment of prisoners shocked international observers
His inhuman cruelty toward animals disturbed everyone deeply
She showed inhuman strength lifting the fallen beam
The athlete's inhuman endurance amazed the spectators completely

definitions: without compassion for misery or suffering; cruel and causing unnecessary pain
examples: The inhumane conditions in the factory were exposed
Keeping animals in such inhumane cages is unacceptable

definitions: tending to obstruct or harm; hostile and unfriendly in nature or influence
having effects that oppose or work against particular interests or purposes
examples: The inimical forces threatened to destroy the alliance
His inimical attitude made cooperation impossible between departments
These policies are inimical to economic growth nationwide
The harsh climate proved inimical to agricultural development

definitions: so good or unusual as to be impossible to copy or imitate successfully
examples: Her inimitable style made her performances unforgettable always
The chef's inimitable recipes remained secret for decades

definitions: existing or occurring at the beginning of something; first in sequence
relating to or denoting the first letter of a name or word
examples: The initial response to the proposal was positive
Initial tests revealed no significant problems with design
Please write your initials on each page here
The initial letter of each chapter was beautifully decorated

definitions: showing the ability to assess and initiate things independently without prompting
examples: The initiative students organized their own study groups
She took an initiative approach to solving problems

definitions: capable of being administered by injection into the body using a syringe
examples: The injectable vaccine provides long-lasting immunity to patients
Injectable medications work faster than oral forms typically

definitions: harmed or hurt physically, especially as a result of an accident
emotionally hurt or offended by someone's words or actions toward them
examples: The injured players left the field immediately today
Several injured passengers were taken to nearby hospitals
She gave him an injured look after his comment
His injured pride prevented him from apologizing properly

definitions: causing or likely to cause damage, harm, or impairment to something
examples: Smoking has injurious effects on your respiratory system
The injurious remarks damaged their professional relationship permanently

definitions: set into a surface as decoration using pieces of different materials
examples: The inlaid marble floor featured intricate geometric patterns
An inlaid wooden box held her precious jewelry collection

definitions: situated in or toward the interior of a country away from the coast
examples: The inland cities experienced different weather patterns entirely
They moved to an inland location for safety reasons

definitions: possessed from birth; natural and instinctive rather than acquired or learned
examples: Her innate musical talent emerged in early childhood
Humans have an innate capacity for language acquisition

definitions: situated inside or further in; internal rather than external in position
relating to the mind, spirit, or soul rather than physical aspects
examples: The inner walls were painted bright yellow yesterday
She explored the inner chambers of the ancient temple
His inner peace remained undisturbed despite the chaos
The meditation helped her connect with inner wisdom

definitions: situated as far inside as possible; at the very center of something
most private and secret; relating to one's deepest thoughts and feelings
examples: The innermost room contained the sacred artifacts carefully
They reached the innermost part of the cave
She revealed her innermost thoughts in the diary
His innermost fears prevented him from taking risks

definitions: not guilty of a crime or offense; free from legal wrongdoing
not intended to cause harm or offense; naive and unsuspecting about worldly matters
examples: The jury found the defendant innocent of all charges
Police confirmed the suspect was innocent after investigation
Her innocent question embarrassed the adults present there
The children's innocent laughter filled the playground today

definitions: not harmful or offensive; unlikely to provoke strong feelings or controversy
examples: The innocuous comment sparked an unexpected debate somehow
What seemed innocuous actually contained hidden dangers inside

definitions: featuring new methods, ideas, or products; creative and original in approach
examples: Their innovative design won the international competition easily
The company's innovative approach revolutionized the industry completely

definitions: too many to be counted; extremely large in number beyond calculation
examples: The night sky contained innumerable stars twinkling brightly
She had received innumerable requests for her autograph

definitions: not objectionable or harmful; unlikely to upset or anger anyone significantly
examples: His inoffensive manner made him popular with everyone
She chose inoffensive topics for the dinner conversation

definitions: not able to be used or operated; not functioning or working properly
not able to be treated by surgery due to medical risks or limitations
examples: The old machine was completely inoperable after years
Several inoperable vehicles blocked the narrow country road
The tumor was inoperable due to its dangerous location
His condition was deemed inoperable by three specialists

definitions: not working or taking effect; failing to perform the intended function
examples: The emergency exit was inoperative during the inspection
Several inoperative streetlights created dangerous conditions at night

definitions: unusually or disproportionately large; excessive beyond normal or reasonable limits
examples: He spent an inordinate amount of time checking emails
The project required inordinate resources to complete successfully

definitions: not consisting of or derived from living matter; relating to compounds not containing carbon
examples: Inorganic fertilizers provide nutrients quickly to growing plants
The geologist studied inorganic minerals in rock formations

definitions: showing an interest in learning or finding out about things; questioning
examples: Her inquiring mind led to scientific discoveries later
He gave her an inquiring look when she arrived

definitions: having or showing an interest in learning things; curious and eager to know
examples: The inquisitive child asked endless questions about everything
Her inquisitive nature made her an excellent researcher

definitions: in a state of mind preventing normal perception, behavior, or social interaction
extremely foolish, irrational or unreasonable; far beyond normal sensible limits
examples: The defendant was declared legally insane by psychiatrists
He exhibited insane behavior during the violent episode
The insane prices at the restaurant shocked everyone there
It's insane to drive in this terrible weather

definitions: impossible to satisfy fully; having an appetite or desire that cannot be satisfied
examples: His insatiable curiosity drove him to explore everywhere
The child had an insatiable appetite for sweet treats

definitions: written, carved, or engraved as a formal or permanent record on something
examples: The inscribed message on the monument honored fallen soldiers
Her name was inscribed on the trophy base permanently

definitions: not confident or assured; uncertain and anxious about oneself or relationships
not firmly fixed or attached; likely to fail or give way physically
examples: She felt insecure about her appearance at the party
His insecure personality made forming relationships difficult constantly
The insecure ladder wobbled dangerously under his weight
The insecure connection caused frequent internet disruptions daily

definitions: showing or feeling no concern for others' feelings; lacking empathy or consideration
not sensitive to physical stimuli; lacking physical sensation or responsiveness
examples: His insensitive comments hurt her feelings deeply yesterday
The insensitive boss ignored employees' personal problems completely
The injured area became insensitive to touch gradually
Some people are insensitive to certain food allergens

definitions: unable to be separated or treated separately; always together or connected
examples: The inseparable friends did everything together since childhood
These two concepts are inseparable in philosophical discussions

definitions: at sea but close to the shore; operating near the coast
examples: Inshore fishing boats returned before the storm arrived
The inshore waters were calmer than the open ocean

definitions: proceeding in a gradual, subtle way but with harmful effects developing slowly
examples: The disease had an insidious onset over several months
Propaganda spread its insidious influence throughout the population

definitions: having or showing an accurate and deep understanding; perceptive and discerning
examples: Her insightful analysis revealed hidden patterns in data
The professor made insightful comments about the novel

definitions: too small or unimportant to be worth consideration; having no influence or value
examples: The difference in price was insignificant between options
He felt insignificant among such accomplished people there

definitions: not expressing genuine feelings; pretending to feel something that is not truly felt
examples: His insincere apology failed to convince anyone present
She gave an insincere smile to her rival

definitions: suggesting something bad or unpleasant in an indirect and unpleasant way
examples: His insinuating remarks about her past upset everyone
She spoke in an insinuating tone about their relationship

definitions: lacking flavor or taste; bland and unappetizing in taste or smell
lacking vigor or interest; dull and boring without distinctive qualities
examples: The insipid soup needed salt and spices desperately
Hospital food often tastes insipid to most patients
The movie's insipid plot bored the entire audience
Her insipid personality made conversation difficult and tedious

definitions: demanding something forcefully and refusing to accept refusal or opposition
continuing for a long time in a way that cannot be ignored
examples: She was insistent that everyone attend the meeting
His insistent demands finally wore down their resistance
The insistent ringing of the alarm woke everyone up
The insistent rain continued throughout the entire night

definitions: showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect toward someone in authority
examples: The insolent teenager talked back to his teachers
Her insolent behavior resulted in immediate suspension yesterday

definitions: unable to be dissolved in a liquid, especially water or other solvents
impossible to solve or explain; having no solution or answer possible
examples: Oil is insoluble in water under normal conditions
The insoluble fiber helps maintain digestive health naturally
They faced an insoluble dilemma with no good options
The mystery remained insoluble despite years of investigation

definitions: unable to pay debts owed; having liabilities exceeding available assets financially
examples: The insolvent company filed for bankruptcy protection immediately
Many businesses became insolvent during the economic crisis

definitions: experiencing or relating to the inability to sleep; affected by chronic insomnia
examples: The insomniac patient tried various remedies for sleep
His insomniac nights were filled with endless worrying

definitions: providing or showing creative or spiritual inspiration; motivating positive action or feeling
examples: Her inspirational speech motivated the entire team greatly
The inspirational story touched millions of readers worldwide

definitions: of extraordinary quality, as if arising from some external creative impulse
filled with the urge or ability to do or feel something creative
examples: The chef's inspired menu delighted all the guests
It was an inspired choice for the leading role
She felt inspired after visiting the art museum
The team played inspired football in the final match
